person_103.name: RobertBoyle
person_103.description: Irish-born chemist and one of the founders of modern chemistry. FRSL.

person_246.name: RobertHooke
person_246.description: Natural philosopher who acted as experimental demonstrator at the Royal Society of London during its early years. Prominent in the study of air and microscopy amongst other subjects. FRSL.

person_036.name: IsaacNewton
person_036.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

person_1005.name: Gottfried WilhelmLeibniz
person_1005.description: A German polymath active as a mathematician, philosopher, scientist and diplomat who invented calculus

person_969.name: HermanBoerhaave
person_969.description: Dutch botanist, chemist, Christian humanist, and physician.

person_388.name: Georg ErnstStahl
person_388.description: German physician, chemist and philosopher who strongly promoted the phlogiston theory.

person_030.name: Antoine-LaurentLavoisier
person_030.description: French chemist and tax farmer (for which he was guillotined). Developed a new nomenclature for chemistry (much of which is still in use today) and argued strongly against the existence of phlogiston. Davy read some of his writings while in Cornwall which he then opposed and throughout his career maintained an ambivalent attitude towards Lavoisierian chemisty. ForMemRSL.

person_143.name: BenjaminThompson
person_143.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

person_524.name: Rene-AntoineRéaumur
person_524.description: French entomologist who developed a widely used temperature scale. ForMemRSL.

person_972.name: Alexis ThérèsePetit
person_972.description: French physicist known for his work on air and steam engines. The Dulong-Petit law of thermodynamics is named after him and his collaborator Pierre-Louis Dulong.

person_153.name: Pierre LouisDulong
person_153.description: French physicist and chemist who worked mostly on specific heats, but also discovered nitrogen chloride around the same time as Davy. ForMemRSL.

person_196.name: Alexander John GaspardMarcet
person_196.description: Genevean-born physician who settled in London and lectured on chemistry at Guy's Hospital. A friend of Davy's. FRSL.

person_121.name: JohnFreeborn
person_121.description: Banker, merchant and British cousul in Rome.

person_951.name: JesusChrist
person_951.description: The central figure of Christianity; a first-century Jewish preacher and religious leader.

person_973.name: Saint Paul
person_973.description: A Christian apostle who spread the teachings of Jesus in the first-century world. For his contributions towards the New Testament, he is generally regarded as one of the most important figures of the Apostolic Age.

person_102.name: Philalethes
person_102.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_213.name: JohnHunter
person_213.description: Leading Scottish surgeon and anatomist who worked in London, holding several major positions. Brother of William Hunter. FRSL.

person_269.name: LuigiGalvani
person_269.description: Italian surgeon and anatomist who carried out experiments with electricity and animals. The term 'galvanism' was named after him

person_974.name: GeorgeDuring
person_974.description: His Majesty's Consul in Triest in 1829 who helped Davy obtain recently caught Torpedos for his experiments.

person_199.name: AlessandroVolta
person_199.description: Professor of experimental physics at the University of Pavia. At the end of the eighteenth century he Invented the Voltaic pile which produced electric current and which Davy shortly dubbed the battery. Davy described meeting him in 1814 in notebook 14/I, p.38. ForMemRSL.

person_888.name: Hans ChristianØrsted
person_888.description: Danish physicist and chemist who won the Copley Medal in 1820 for his electro-chemical experiments and discoveries; he had become a professor at the University of Copenhagen in 1806.

person_026.name: HenryCavendish
person_026.description: A central figure in English natural philosophy and chemistry, among other research he determined the density of the earth and discovered what would later be named hydrogen. He was one of the people who helped appoint Davy to the Royal Institution. Following his death in 1810 Davy delivered a widely-quoted eulogy on Cavendish and later arranged for some of his apparatus to be transferred to the Royal Institution. FRSL.

person_525.name: JohnWalsh
person_525.description: Nabob and later an MP he experimented on the electrical properties of torpedo fish. FRSL.

person_511.name: Martial
person_511.description: Roman poet born in Hispania (modern Spain) best known for his twelve books of Epigrams, published in Rome between AD 86 and 103.

person_074.name: Franz JosefGall
person_074.description: German-born, he later worked in Paris on phrenology.

person_975.name: Johann GasparSpurzheim
person_975.description: a German physician who became one of the chief proponents of phrenology.

person_981.name: MadamaGuirridie
person_981.description: Untraced, but probably connected to 78 Piazza Poli in Rome

person_101.name: Ambrosio
person_101.description: A fictional character in Humphry Davy's Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_977.name: Stephan LudwigJacobi
person_977.description: German landowner and inventor who developed the first trout hatchery in Germany.

person_070.name: JaneDavy
person_070.description: Daughter of Charles Kerr, an Antiguan merchant who made his fortune in highly dubious circumstances. Following his death she moved to Britain where she married Schukbrugh Apreece who died in 1807. After running a successful literary salon in Edinburgh she moved to London where she met Davy and they married on 11 April 1812 two days after he had been knighted by the Prince Regent.

person_127.name: JohnMurray
person_127.description: Publisher of many of the key literary and scientific texts of the time, including by Byron, Austen, Davy. Published The Quarterly Journal of Science (closely likned to the Royal Institution) as well as Davy's Six Discourses (1827), Salmonia (1828) and Consolations in Travel (1830).

person_194.name: EdwardJenner
person_194.description: Lived in Berkeley, Gloucestershire, where he pioneered vacination, especially for smallpox. FRSL.

person_898.name: Germaine deStaël
person_898.description: Commonly known as Madame de Staël; a woman of letters and political theorist.

person_108.name: Onuphrio
person_108.description: Onuphiro is the name of a fictional character in the dialogues of Davy's Consolations in Travel. The anglicized version of the name is Humphry.

person_916.name: Hipparchus
person_916.description: a Greek astronomer, geographer, and mathematician. He is considered the founder of trigonometry, but is most famous for his incidental discovery of the precession of the equinoxes.

person_399.name: John Frederick WilliamHerschel
person_399.description: Son of William Herschel and a ploymathic mathematician, natural philosopher, astronomer and chemist who coined the word photograph. Unsuccesful in being elected President of the Royal Society of London, he later became Master of the Mint. FRSL.

person_140.name: Socrates
person_140.description: Greek philosopher whose work survives mostly through the writings of his pupil Plato. Executed by the democratic Athenian state for sedition.

person_979.name: PeterRomanov
person_979.description: Peter I of Russia, also known as Peter the Great.  The first emperor of all Russia who was responsible for huge cultural changes, replacing some of the traditionalist and medieval social and political systems with ones that were modern, scientific, Westernized, and based on radical Enlightenment.

person_115.name: Moses
person_115.description: According to the Old Testament Hebrew prophet who is considered the most important prophet in Judaism and one of the most important prophets in Christianity and other religions.

person_564.name: Alaric
person_564.description: Leader of the Visigoths who led the sack of Rome in 410 CE.

person_919.name: Attila
person_919.description: The ruler of the Huns from 434 until his death.

person_417.name: Archimedes
person_417.description: Ancient Greek mathematician, physicist, engineer, astronomer and inventor from Syracuse in Sicily.

person_324.name: RogerBacon
person_324.description: Medieval English philosopher and Franciscan friar.

person_406.name: Alfred
person_406.description: King of the West Saxons from 871 to 886, and King of the Anglo-Saxons from 886 until his death in 899.

person_114.name: Muhammad
person_114.description: The Holy Prophet and founder of Islam.

person_980.name: Tamerlane
person_980.description: a Turco-Mongol conqueror who founded the Timurid Empire in and around modern-day Afghanistan, Iran, and Central Asia, becoming the first ruler of the Timurid dynasty.

person_920.name: GengisKhan
person_920.description: The founder and first khan of the Mongol Empire.

person_666.name: BertholdSchwarz
person_666.description: German (or in some accounts Danish or Greek) alchemist, credited with the invention of gunpowder.

person_759.name: JohnCalvin
person_759.description: French theologian, pastor and reformer in Geneva during the Protestant Reformation.

person_982.name: St. Peter
person_982.description: one of the Twelve Apostles of Jesus Christ and one of the first leaders of the early Christian Church. Catholic tradition accredits Peter as the first bishop of Rome‍, or pope‍, and also as the first bishop of Antioch.

person_795.name: Jupiter
person_795.description: Also known as Jove. The god of the sky and thunder, and king of the gods in ancient Roman religion and mythology.

person_984.name: Clement XIV
person_984.description: Pope Clement XIV born Giovanni Vincenzo Antonio Ganganelli, was head of the Catholic Church and ruler of the Papal States from 19 May 1769 to his death in September 1774.

place_414.name: Phlegraean Fields
place_414.description: A large region of supervolcanic calderas situated to the west of Naples, Italy.

place_156.name: Naples
place_156.description: Naples is the regional capital of Campania in Italy. It is located beneath the volcano, Vesuvius.

place_266.name: Rhine
place_266.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

place_217.name: River Danube
place_217.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

place_260.name: Drava River
place_260.description: The Drava is a river in central southern Europe and is the fifth longest tributary of the Danube.

place_214.name: Sava River
place_214.description: The Sava River, 990km in length, rises in Slovenia (Carnolia) and is the largest tributary of the Danube by volume of water.

place_192.name: Illyrian Alps
place_192.description: Illyria was the name of a mountainous region in the western part of the Balkan Peninsula in south-eastern Europe.

place_196.name: Styria
place_196.description: Styria is a state in the south-east of Austria.

place_194.name: Julian Alps
place_194.description: The Julian Alps are a mountain range in the Southern Limestone Alps, Slovenia. Mount Triglav is the highest point.

place_216.name: Ljubljana
place_216.description: Also known as Laybach or Laibach. Ljubljana is the capital city of Slovenia.

place_519.name: Trieste
place_519.description: Trieste is the capital city of the Friuli Venezia Giulia region in north-east Italy. A port city, it occupies a thin strip of land between the Adriatic coast and Slovenia’s border on the limestone-dominated Karst Plateau.

place_730.name: Milan
place_730.description: A city in northern Italy, and the capital of Lombardy.

place_1197.name: Mola di Gaeta
place_1197.description: Italian village on the coast between Rome and Naples.

place_728.name: Rimini
place_728.description: A city in north-eastern Italy located on the coast of the Adriatic Sea.

place_1191.name: Mediterranean Sea
place_1191.description: Connected to the Atlantic Ocean and almost completely surrounded by land.

place_704.name: Bay of Naples
place_704.description: The Bay (or Gulf) of Naples is located on the south-western coast of Italy, with Naples to the north, Vesuvius to the east, and the Sorrento Peninsula to the south.

place_106.name: Lakes of Killarney
place_106.description: Three lakes (Lough Leane, Muckross Lake - also called Middle Lake, and Upper Lake) surrounded by the MacGillycuddy's Reeks and now part of Killarney National Park.

place_1199.name: Kerry
place_1199.description: County in the peninsular southwest of Ireland.

place_1198.name: Mangarton
place_1198.description: A Mountain above a lake in Killarney, Ireland.

place_437.name: Northern Ireland
place_437.description: Northern Ireland consists of six counties to the north-east of the island, not including the Republic of Ireland county, Donegal, to the west.

place_144.name: Keeper Hill
place_144.description: One of the Silvermine Mountains of County Tipperary, Ireland.

place_007.name: Limerick
place_007.description: Limerick is a city in Ireland, set in Munster province in the south of the country.

place_070.name: Mucrish
place_070.description: Muckish, one of the Derryveagh Mountains. See the poem 'Mucrish and Arokil, ye pair...' in Tait's Edinburgh Magazine for 1836, vol. iii, p. 252. See also Memoirs, vol. 1, pp. 287 ff.

place_1230.name: Iona
place_1230.description: an island in the Inner Hebrides, off the Ross of Mull on the western coast of Scotland.

place_256.name: Wurzen Pass
place_256.description: Wurzen Pass is a mountain pass in a col of the Karawanks Mountain range between the Austrian state of Carinthia and the the Slovenian Kranjska Gora. It is named after the town of Podkoren (Wurzen).

place_237.name: Iceland
place_237.description: A Nordic island country between the North Atlantic and Arctic Oceans.

place_1210.name: Piazza Poli
place_1210.description: Davy refers to No.78 Piazza di Poli near the Trevi Fountain in Rome, presumably as somewhere he stayed.

place_1209.name: Palazzo Fiano
place_1209.description: Historic building in Rome, with a painted ceiling featuring many mythological figures and a hall of mirrors.

place_199.name: The Colosseum
place_199.description: The Colosseum, the largest amphitheatre ever built, is located in the centre of Rome. Now a ruin, its construction began 2,000 years ago.

place_878.name: United States
place_878.description: The U.S. is a country of 50 states covering a vast swath of North America, with Alaska in the northwest and Hawaii extending the nation’s presence into the Pacific Ocean.

place_1206.name: Baltic Sea
place_1206.description: The Baltic Sea is an arm of the Atlantic Ocean that is enclosed by Denmark, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Latvia, Lithuania, Poland, Russia, Sweden, and the North and Central European Plain.

place_582.name: Black Sea
place_582.description: The Black Sea is a marginal Mediterranean sea lying between Europe and Asia, east of the Balkans, south of the East European Plain, west of the Caucasus, and north of Anatolia.

place_825.name: River Thames
place_825.description: The River Thames, known alternatively in parts as the River Isis, is a river that flows through southern England including London.

place_1207.name: Delaware River
place_1207.description: a major river in the Mid-Atlantic region of the United States and is the longest free-flowing river in the Eastern United States.

place_1208.name: St. Lawrence River
place_1208.description: a large international river in the middle latitudes of North America connecting the Great Lakes to the North Atlantic Ocean.

place_897.name: France
place_897.description: France, officially the French Republic, is a country located primarily in Western Europe.

place_208.name: Athens
place_208.description: Athens is the capital city of Greece.

place_222.name: Africa
place_222.description: The world's second-largest and second-most populous continent.

place_911.name: Niger
place_911.description: The main river of West Africa, extending about 4,180 km.

place_518.name: Ganges
place_518.description: The Ganges is a river in Asia running through India and Bangladesh. It is part of the third largest river on earth.

place_530.name: Apennines
place_530.description: The Apennines are a range of mountains that run down the spine of peninsular Italy.

place_1212.name: Arabian Peninsula
place_1212.description: a peninsula in West Asia, situated northeast of Africa on the Arabian Plate. It includes the territories of includes Bahrain, Kuwait, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Yemen, as well as southern Iraq and Jordan. In the classical era, the Sinai Peninsula was also considered a part of Arabia.

place_949.name: Delphi
place_949.description: An ancient sacred precinct in Greece, the ancient Greeks considered the centre of the world to be in Delphi.

place_1213.name: Thebes, Egypt
place_1213.description: an ancient Egyptian city located along the Nile, its ruins lie within the modern Egyptian city of Luxor.

place_981.name: Memphis
place_981.description: The ancient capital of Inebu-hedj, the first nome of Lower Egypt. Its ruins are located in the vicinity of the present-day village of Mit Rahina.

place_982.name: Babylon
place_982.description: An ancient city located on the lower Euphrates river in southern Mesopotamia, within modern-day Iraq.

place_1214.name: Troy
place_1214.description: an ancient city located in present-day Hisarlik, Turkey. It is best known as the setting for the Trojan War.

place_1215.name: Tyre
place_1215.description: one of the earliest Phoenician metropolises and the legendary birthplace of Europa, her brothers Cadmus and Phoenix, as well as Carthage's founder Dido

place_1216.name: Niniveh
place_1216.description: an ancient Assyrian city of Upper Mesopotamia, located in the modern-day city of Mosul in northern Iraq.

place_1217.name: Carthage
place_1217.description: an ancient city on the eastern side of the Lake of Tunis in what is now Tunisia. Carthage was one of the most important trading hubs of the Ancient Mediterranean and one of the most affluent cities of the classical world.

place_154.name: St. Peter's
place_154.description: St Peter's is a church built in the Renaissance style located in the Vatican City, west of the River Tiber.

otherwork_042.author: Humphry Davy

otherwork_286.author: Humphry Davy
